item.title: Free Cnc project files.
item.description: Some nice cnc projects, should give these a try.

item.title: Sandman The Audio Book
item.description: Just finished this, and it was glorious. Great voice acting, and I could almost see the comic strips from so long ago in my mind while reading. Weither you have good memories of the graphics novel, or you have ignored it because “comics aren’t real books”, I warmly recommended checking out this epic version of the story of the endless.

item.title: Jellyfin - Plex replacement?
item.description: “Jellyfin is the volunteer-built media solution that puts you in control of your media. Stream to any device from your own server, with no strings attached. Your media, your server, your way.”

item.title: httpstat - great curl visualization
item.description: Great little tool for seeing http timing stats. TIL, httpstat: visualizes curl(1) statistics in a way of beauty and clarity -- nifty and instant replacement for my own curl timing script... GitHub: https://t.co/L1jpopqyyq pic.twitter.com/eNzCQQzDoW — Ilya Grigorik (@igrigorik) August 12, 2020

item.title: More praise for magit
item.description: I know I’ve mentioned magit before here, but I think this post shows a lot of the power you get from magit, which now makes it preferable to me even over the CLI.

item.title: Avoid 'no data' in your prometheus queries
item.description: CLOSED: [2020-08-10 Mon 20:57] Have some Prometheus queries that sometimes give no results? For instance error rate when there are no errors. Just append ~or vector(0) and the query will return 0 instead of an empty vector.

item.title: Goodbye 182 day streak
item.description: Today I’m ending my love affair with duolingo, have just signed up for a year of memrise. Let’s see if I can finally git gud at Russian :)

item.title: Org mode reference card
item.description: Great little reference for org mode syntax.

item.title: Magit Forge on macOS
item.description: I’ve tried many editor git integrations over the years, in Vim, VS Code, IntelliJ, Sublime, as well as various git guis. However I’ve never found something nearly as powerful and efficient day to day as working on the command line. While I will probably never give up the command line, with Emacs’ Magit I’ve finally found a valuable companion which feels as powerful and efficient as the cli interface. The magit status window is a super powerful base point for most git operations.

item.title: Modern rust alternatives for Unix classics
i3-grid - easily handle floating windows in i3
item.description: i3 is my favorite window manager ever, and it works great for tiling, but sometimes you need a floating window, and typically that has meant resorting to the dreaded mouse, or clumsy keybindings. i3-grid promises to fix this. Check out the demo from the README, it’s pretty neat!
